q: What is the primary source of federal tax law in the United States?
The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) is part of the Department of the Treasury.
What are the types of tax law authority?
o: Statutory (IRC), administrative (regulations, rulings), and judicial (court cases)

q: Match the authority type with its source:
Treasury regulations are the official interpretation of the IRC by the ______.
What is a revenue ruling?
o: Official IRS interpretation of how the law applies to a specific set of facts

q: Revenue rulings are published in the Internal Revenue Bulletin.
What is a private letter ruling (PLR)?
o: IRS ruling issued to a specific taxpayer for a specific transaction

q: PLRs cannot be cited as ______ by other taxpayers.
What is the Tax Court?
o: A federal court where taxpayers can challenge IRS determinations without first paying the tax

q: Match the court with its jurisdiction:
What is gross income?
o: All income from whatever source derived unless specifically excluded

q: Gross income includes both ordinary income and capital gains.
What is adjusted gross income (AGI)?
AGI is calculated ______ determining the standard or itemized deduction.
What are above-the-line deductions?
o: Deductions subtracted from gross income to arrive at AGI

q: Match the deduction type with its example:
What is taxable income?
o: AGI minus the greater of standard or itemized deductions minus qualified business income deduction

q: Taxable income is multiplied by the tax ______ to calculate tax liability.
What is the standard deduction?
o: A fixed amount that reduces taxable income based on filing status

q: The standard deduction is indexed annually for inflation.
What are itemized deductions?
o: Specific deductions a taxpayer can claim instead of the standard deduction

q: Common itemized deductions include medical expenses, state taxes, mortgage interest, and ______.
What is the medical expense deduction threshold?
Match the itemized deduction with its limitation:
What is the SALT deduction limitation?
o: State and local taxes deduction capped at $10,000

q: The SALT limitation applies to state income taxes, property taxes, and ______ taxes.
What is the mortgage interest deduction?
o: Deduction for interest on acquisition indebtedness up to $750,000

q: Home equity loan interest is not deductible unless funds are used to buy, build, or improve the home.
What is the charitable contribution deduction?
o: Deduction for donations to qualified charitable organizations

q: Cash charitable contributions are generally limited to ______ of AGI.
What is the casualty and theft loss deduction?
o: Losses from federally declared disasters, reduced by floors

q: Personal casualty losses are limited to federally declared disasters.
What is filing status?
o: A category that determines tax rates, standard deduction, and eligibility for certain benefits

q: Match the filing status with its description:
Head of household status requires maintaining a home for a ______.
What is a qualifying child dependency test?
o: Relationship, age, residency, and support tests to qualify as a dependent

q: A qualifying child must be under age 19, or under 24 if a full-time student.
What is a qualifying relative?
o: A dependent who meets relationship, gross income, and support tests

q: Qualifying relatives must have gross income below the ______ amount.
What is the child tax credit?
o: A credit for qualifying children under age 17

q: Match the tax benefit with its type:
The child tax credit begins to phase out at higher ______ levels.
What is the earned income tax credit (EITC)?
o: A refundable credit for low-to-moderate income workers

q: The EITC is refundable, meaning excess credit is paid as a refund.
What is the child and dependent care credit?
o: Credit for expenses to care for qualifying individuals while taxpayer works

q: The dependent care credit is based on a percentage of qualifying ______.
What is the American Opportunity Tax Credit (AOTC)?
o: Credit for qualified higher education expenses for first four years of college

q: Match the education benefit with its characteristic:
The AOTC maximum credit is $______ per eligible student.
What is the Lifetime Learning Credit?
o: Credit for qualified tuition expenses with no limit on years

q: The Lifetime Learning Credit is nonrefundable.
What is self-employment tax?
o: Social Security and Medicare taxes on self-employment income

q: Self-employment tax rate is ______% on net self-employment income.
What is the SE tax deduction?
o: Deduction for 50% of self-employment tax as an adjustment to income

q: The SE tax deduction is ______ the line.
What is estimated tax?
o: Quarterly payments of income and self-employment tax when withholding is insufficient

q: Estimated tax payments are due in April, June, September, and January.
What is the penalty for underpayment of estimated tax?
Safe harbor to avoid penalty is paying ______% of prior year tax.
What is the alternative minimum tax (AMT)?
o: A parallel tax system to ensure minimum tax payment

q: AMT eliminates certain deductions and preferences.
What is the AMT exemption?
o: An amount excluded from AMT taxable income, phased out at higher incomes

q: Match the adjustment with AMT treatment:
What is a capital asset?
o: Property held for investment or personal use, not inventory or business property

q: Capital assets include stocks, bonds, personal residence, and ______.
What is the holding period for long-term capital gains?
Long-term capital gains are taxed at preferential rates.
What are the long-term capital gains tax rates?
Net investment income tax (NIIT) adds ______% to investment income for high earners.
What is capital loss limitation?
o: Net capital losses limited to $3,000 per year against ordinary income

q: Match the capital asset treatment with its rule:
Capital losses in excess of $3,000 can be ______ forward.
What is Section 1231 property?
o: Depreciable business property and real property used in trade or business held over 1 year

q: Section 1231 gains are treated as long-term capital gains.
What is Section 1245 recapture?
o: Recharacterizes gain on depreciable personal property as ordinary income

q: Section 1245 recapture applies to the lesser of gain or ______ taken.
What is Section 1250 recapture?
o: Recapture of excess depreciation on real property as ordinary income

q: Unrecaptured Section 1250 gain is taxed at a maximum rate of ______%.
What is like-kind exchange under Section 1031?
o: Tax-deferred exchange of real property held for productive use or investment

q: Like-kind exchanges apply only to real property after 2017.
What is boot in a like-kind exchange?
o: Non-like-kind property or cash received in the exchange

q: Boot received in a like-kind exchange is ______ to the extent of gain.
Rearrange the individual tax calculation steps:
What is installment sale?
o: Sale where at least one payment is received after the tax year of sale

q: Gain on installment sales is recognized as ______ are received.
What is the installment gross profit percentage?
o: Gross profit divided by contract price

q: Match the installment sale element with its treatment:
What is the Section 121 exclusion?
o: Exclusion of gain on sale of principal residence

q: Section 121 allows exclusion of up to $250,000 ($500,000 MFJ) on home sale gain.
What are the Section 121 requirements?
o: Owned and used as principal residence for 2 of last 5 years

q: Section 121 can be used only once every ______ years.
What is passive activity?
o: Trade or business in which the taxpayer does not materially participate

q: Rental activities are generally treated as passive.
What is the passive loss limitation?
o: Passive losses can only offset passive income

q: Suspended passive losses are allowed when the activity is ______.
What is the real estate professional exception?
o: Exception allowing real estate professionals to treat rental as non-passive

q: Real estate professionals must spend more than ______ hours in real property trades.
What is the $25,000 rental loss allowance?
o: Exception allowing active participants to deduct up to $25,000 of rental losses

q: The $25,000 allowance phases out starting at AGI of $______.
What is at-risk limitation?
o: Losses limited to the taxpayer's amount at risk

q: Match the loss limitation with its order of application:
What is basis in property?
o: The starting point for measuring gain or loss on disposition

q: Cost basis equals purchase price plus ______.
What is adjusted basis?
o: Original basis adjusted for improvements and depreciation

q: Adjusted basis increases with ______ and decreases with depreciation.
What is the basis of inherited property?
o: Generally fair market value at date of death

q: Inherited property receives a stepped-up ______.
What is the basis of gifted property?
o: Generally donor's basis with adjustments for gift tax paid

q: For gifts at a loss, basis is the lower of donor's basis or FMV.
What is a wash sale?
o: Sale of stock at a loss with repurchase within 30 days before or after

q: Wash sale losses are ______.
What is related party transaction?
o: Transaction between family members or controlled entities with special rules

q: Losses on sales to related parties are ______.
What is IRA contribution?
o: Contribution to Individual Retirement Account with potential deduction

q: Match the IRA type with its tax treatment:
Traditional IRA contributions are ______ if eligible.
What is Roth IRA?
o: After-tax contributions with tax-free qualified withdrawals

q: Roth IRA qualified distributions are tax-free.
What is 401(k) plan?
o: Employer-sponsored retirement plan with pre-tax deferrals

q: 401(k) contributions reduce current ______ income.
What is required minimum distribution (RMD)?
o: Mandatory withdrawals from retirement accounts starting at age 73

q: Failure to take RMD results in a ______% penalty.
What is early withdrawal penalty?
Certain exceptions waive the early withdrawal penalty.
What is a sole proprietorship?
o: Unincorporated business owned by one person, reported on Schedule C

q: Sole proprietor income is reported on Schedule ______.
What is a partnership for tax purposes?
o: Association of two or more persons to carry on a trade or business

q: Match the entity with its tax form:
Partnerships are ______ entities for income tax purposes.
What is a partner's distributive share?
o: Partner's allocation of partnership income, gain, loss, deduction, and credit

q: Partners receive Schedule K-1 reporting their distributive share.
What is partner's basis in partnership interest?
o: Capital contribution plus share of liabilities plus income minus losses minus distributions

q: Partner's basis is reduced by ______.
What is a guaranteed payment?
o: Payment to partner for services or capital without regard to partnership income

q: Guaranteed payments are ______ to the partnership.
What is partnership formation?
o: Generally tax-free when property is contributed for partnership interest

q: Section 721 provides for tax-free partnership ______.
What is hot asset in partnership?
o: Unrealized receivables and inventory that trigger ordinary income on sale

q: Match the partnership asset with its treatment:
What is an S corporation?
o: Corporation electing pass-through taxation under Subchapter S

q: S corporations are limited to ______ shareholders.
What are S corporation eligibility requirements?
o: Domestic corporation, 100 shareholders, one class of stock, eligible shareholders

q: S corporations cannot have ______ shareholders.
What is S corporation basis?
o: Stock basis plus direct loans from shareholder to corporation

q: S corporation debt does not increase shareholder ______ unless a direct loan.
What is built-in gains tax?
o: Tax on appreciation that existed when C corporation converted to S

q: Built-in gains tax applies for ______ years after conversion.
What is a C corporation?
o: Standard corporation subject to entity-level tax

q: C corporations face double taxation on dividends.
What is the corporate tax rate?
Corporate taxable income equals gross income minus ______.
What is dividends received deduction (DRD)?
o: Deduction for corporations receiving dividends from other corporations

q: Match the ownership level with DRD percentage:
What is corporate charitable deduction limitation?
o: Limited to 10% of taxable income before certain deductions

q: Corporate charitable contributions excess can be carried forward ______ years.
What is accumulated earnings tax?
o: Penalty tax on corporations retaining earnings beyond reasonable needs

q: The accumulated earnings credit provides safe harbor of $______.
What is personal holding company tax?
o: Penalty tax on corporations with primarily passive income owned by few individuals

q: PHC tax is imposed at ______%.
What is corporate formation under Section 351?
o: Tax-free transfer of property for stock if transferors control corporation

q: Section 351 requires ______% control immediately after exchange.
What is corporate liquidation?
o: Distribution of corporate assets to shareholders in complete termination

q: Shareholders recognize gain or loss on liquidating ______.
What is a corporate reorganization?
Match the reorganization type with its description:
What is an LLC for tax purposes?
o: Entity that can elect to be taxed as partnership, corporation, or disregarded

q: Single-member LLCs default to ______ entity status.
What is qualified business income deduction (QBI)?
o: Section 199A deduction for pass-through business income up to 20%

q: QBI deduction is limited to ______% of qualified business income.
What is specified service trade or business (SSTB)?
o: Service businesses like health, law, and consulting subject to QBI limitations

q: SSTBs may be limited or excluded from QBI deduction at higher incomes.
What is employment tax?
o: Social Security and Medicare taxes on wages

q: FICA tax rate for employees is ______%.
What is FUTA?
o: Federal Unemployment Tax Act - employer-only tax

q: FUTA applies to the first $______ of wages.
What is the additional Medicare tax?
Additional Medicare tax is paid only by ______.
What is gift tax?
o: Tax on transfer of property during life without adequate consideration

q: Match the transfer tax with its trigger:
The annual gift tax exclusion is $______ per donee.
What is the unlimited marital deduction?
o: Unlimited gift and estate tax deduction for transfers to citizen spouse

q: Gifts to non-citizen spouses have a higher annual exclusion.
What is estate tax?
o: Tax on transfer of property at death

q: The estate tax exclusion is $______ million (2024).
What is portability?
o: Transfer of deceased spouse's unused exclusion to surviving spouse

q: Portability requires timely filing of estate ______.
What is generation-skipping transfer tax?
o: Tax on transfers to grandchildren or skip persons

q: GST tax is imposed at the maximum estate tax rate.
What is business law contract formation?
o: Offer, acceptance, consideration, capacity, and legality

q: Match the contract element with its definition:
A contract requires mutual ______.
What is the Statute of Frauds?
o: Requirement that certain contracts be in writing to be enforceable

q: Contracts for sale of land must be in ______.
What is UCC Article 2?
o: Uniform Commercial Code governing sale of goods

q: UCC applies to transactions in ______.
What is breach of contract?
Remedies for breach include damages, specific performance, and ______.
What is an agency relationship?
o: Fiduciary relationship where agent acts on behalf of principal

q: Match the agency concept with its description:
Agents owe fiduciary duties to their ______.
What is principal liability for agent acts?
o: Principal liable for authorized acts and acts within scope of authority

q: Respondeat superior makes employers liable for employee ______ within scope.
What is a negotiable instrument?
o: Written promise or order to pay money meeting UCC requirements

q: Negotiable instruments include checks, promissory notes, and ______.
What are the requirements for negotiability?
o: Written, signed, unconditional promise/order to pay fixed sum, payable on demand or at definite time

q: Holder in due course takes instrument free of ______ defenses.
What is secured transaction?
o: Transaction where creditor has security interest in debtor's property

q: Match the secured transaction term with its meaning:
Perfection is typically achieved by filing a ______.
What is a debtor's rights in secured transactions?
o: Right to redeem collateral by paying debt before disposition

q: Debtor may redeem collateral by paying the ______ amount.
What is bankruptcy?
o: Legal process for debtors to resolve debts

q: Chapter 7 bankruptcy is ______.
What is Chapter 11 bankruptcy?
Chapter 13 is for individuals with regular ______.
What is the automatic stay?
o: Immediate halt to collection actions upon bankruptcy filing

q: The automatic stay stops all ______ efforts.
What is a discharge in bankruptcy?
o: Release from personal liability for certain debts

q: Some debts like student loans and taxes are not ______ in bankruptcy.
What are non-dischargeable debts?
o: Certain taxes, student loans, child support, and debts from fraud

q: Match the debt with its dischargeability:
What is professional ethics for CPAs?
o: AICPA Code of Professional Conduct governing ethical behavior

q: CPAs must maintain ______ in all professional services.
What is CPA independence?
o: Freedom from relationships that could impair objectivity

q: Independence includes both independence in fact and in ______.
What is Circular 230?
o: Treasury regulations governing practice before the IRS

q: Circular 230 applies to CPAs, attorneys, and enrolled ______.
What is due diligence in tax practice?
o: Making reasonable inquiry to determine correctness of positions

q: Tax preparers must exercise due ______ in preparing returns.
What is a tax return preparer penalty?
o: Penalty for understating liability due to unreasonable positions or willful conduct

q: Match the preparer penalty with its trigger:
What is the substantial authority standard?
o: Standard requiring greater than one-third to one-half likelihood of success

q: Undisclosed positions require ______ authority.
What is the reasonable basis standard?
o: Standard requiring more than 20% likelihood of success with disclosure

q: Disclosed positions require at least ______ basis.
What is taxpayer confidentiality?
o: Duty to protect client tax information from unauthorized disclosure

q: Section 7216 imposes ______ penalties for improper disclosure.
Rearrange the tax controversy process:
What is the statute of limitations for assessment?
o: Generally 3 years from later of due date or filing date

q: The statute extends to 6 years for omission of more than ______% of income.
What is the statute of limitations for collection?
There is no statute for ______ returns.
What is innocent spouse relief?
o: Relief from joint liability when spouse was unaware of understatement

q: Innocent spouse relief is available under Section ______.
What is separation of liability relief?
o: Allocating joint tax liability between former spouses

q: Separation of liability requires the spouses to be ______.
What is equitable relief?
o: Relief available when other innocent spouse provisions don't apply

q: Equitable relief is found in Section 6015(f).
What is IRS Appeals?
o: Administrative review of IRS determinations before litigation

q: Appeals is ______ from IRS examination.
What is the 30-day letter?
o: IRS letter proposing adjustments with right to appeal

q: The 30-day letter allows the taxpayer to request ______ review.
What is the 90-day letter?
o: Statutory notice of deficiency allowing Tax Court petition

q: The 90-day letter is also called the notice of ______.
What is tax fraud?
o: Intentional evasion of tax with fraudulent intent

q: Civil fraud penalty is ______% of the underpayment.
What is the accuracy-related penalty?
o: 20% penalty for negligence or substantial understatement

q: Match the penalty with its trigger:
What is substantial understatement?
o: Understatement exceeding greater of $5,000 or 10% of correct tax

q: Substantial understatement penalty can be avoided with ______ disclosure.
What is failure to file penalty?
o: 5% per month up to 25% for not filing return

q: Failure to file penalty is reduced by failure to pay penalty when both apply.
What is failure to pay penalty?
o: 0.5% per month up to 25% for not paying tax due

q: Combined failure to file and pay penalties max at ______% per month.
What is reasonable cause?
o: Defense to penalties based on ordinary business care and prudence

q: Reasonable cause may waive ______ penalties.
What is first-time penalty abatement?
o: Administrative waiver for taxpayers with clean compliance history

q: FTA requires compliance for the prior ______ years.
What is wage garnishment?
o: IRS collection of unpaid tax from wages

q: IRS can levy wages to collect delinquent ______.
What is IRS lien?
o: Legal claim against property for unpaid taxes

q: Federal tax lien attaches to all ______ of the taxpayer.
What is IRS levy?
o: Actual seizure of property to satisfy tax debt

q: Levies can seize bank accounts, wages, and other ______.
What is offer in compromise?
o: Agreement to settle tax debt for less than full amount

q: OIC may be based on doubt as to collectibility or ______.
What is installment agreement?
o: Monthly payment plan for tax debt

q: Streamlined installment agreement is available for debts of $______ or less.
What is Currently Not Collectible (CNC)?
o: Status when taxpayer cannot pay and IRS suspends collection

q: CNC status does not stop the accrual of ______.
What is withholding on wages?
o: Employer's collection of income and FICA taxes from wages

q: Employers must deposit withheld taxes according to IRS ______.
What is Form W-2?
o: Statement of wages and taxes withheld issued by employer

q: W-2 must be provided to employees by January ______.
What is Form 1099?
o: Information return for various types of payments

q: Match the 1099 form with its purpose:
What is Form W-4?
W-4 determines the amount of income tax ______.
What is trust fund recovery penalty?
o: Personal liability for person responsible for unpaid withholding taxes

q: TFRP equals ______% of unpaid trust fund taxes.
What is responsible person for trust fund penalty?
o: Person with authority over financial decisions and willful failure

q: Multiple responsible persons can be held ______ liable.
What is worker classification?
o: Determining if worker is employee or independent contractor

q: Misclassification results in liability for unpaid ______ taxes.
What is common law employee test?
o: Behavioral control, financial control, and type of relationship

q: Match the classification factor with its category:
What is Section 530 relief?
o: Relief from employment tax liability for reasonable classification

q: Section 530 requires ______ treatment of similar workers.
What is tax shelter?
o: Arrangement primarily designed to reduce taxes

q: Abusive tax shelters may trigger ______ penalties.
What is reportable transaction?
Listed transactions are the most serious type of ______ transactions.
What is economic substance doctrine?
o: Transaction must have economic purpose beyond tax benefits

q: Lacking economic substance triggers ______% penalty.
What is step transaction doctrine?
o: Treating separate steps as single integrated transaction

q: Step transaction may ______ intended tax benefits.
What is substance over form?
o: Tax consequences based on actual economic substance not legal form

q: IRS can recharacterize transactions based on ______.
What is assignment of income doctrine?
o: Income taxed to person who earns it regardless of assignment

q: Assignment of income prevents shifting income to ______ taxpayers.
What is sham transaction?
Sham transactions are ______ for tax purposes.
What is kiddie tax?
o: Taxing child's unearned income at parent's rate

q: Kiddie tax applies to children under age ______.
What is net operating loss (NOL)?
o: Business loss that can offset income in other years

q: NOLs can be carried forward ______.
What is the NOL deduction limitation?
The 80% limitation applies to NOLs arising after ______.
What is excess business loss limitation?
o: Limits business losses for non-corporate taxpayers

q: Excess business losses become NOL ______.
What is hobby loss?
o: Loss from activity not engaged in for profit

q: Hobby losses cannot offset ______ income.
What is Section 183?
Presumption of profit motive requires profit in ______ of 5 years.
What is home office deduction?
o: Deduction for business use of home space

q: Home office must be used regularly and ______ for business.
What is simplified home office method?
o: $5 per square foot up to 300 square feet

q: The simplified method allows maximum deduction of $______.
What is business vehicle deduction?
o: Deduction for business use of vehicle using standard mileage or actual expenses

q: Standard mileage rate is set annually by the ______.
What is Section 179 expense?
o: Election to expense cost of qualifying property in year placed in service

q: Section 179 deduction is limited to business ______ for the year.
What is bonus depreciation?
o: Additional first-year depreciation for qualified property

q: Bonus depreciation was 100% through ______.
What is listed property?
o: Property subject to special substantiation and depreciation rules

q: Listed property includes vehicles and ______ equipment.
What is MACRS?
o: Modified Accelerated Cost Recovery System for depreciation

q: MACRS uses ______ conventions for determining depreciation start.
What is mid-quarter convention?
o: Used when more than 40% of property placed in service in last quarter

q: Mid-quarter convention treats property as placed in service at ______ of quarter.
What is amortization of intangibles?
o: Spreading cost of intangibles over useful life or 15 years

q: Section 197 intangibles are amortized over ______ years.
What is organizational expense?
o: Expenses to form a business entity

q: Organizational expenses can be deducted up to $______ immediately.
What is start-up cost?
o: Costs incurred before business begins active operations

q: Start-up costs over $5,000 are amortized over ______ months.
What is interest tracing?
o: Determining character of interest based on use of proceeds

q: Interest character depends on how loan proceeds are ______.
What is limitation on business interest?
o: Section 163(j) limits business interest deduction to 30% of ATI

q: Section 163(j) has exception for small businesses under $______ million.
What is S corporation AAA?
o: Accumulated Adjustments Account tracking post-1982 S corp income

q: AAA tracks S corporation ______ and losses.
What is S corporation E&P?
o: Earnings and Profits from C corporation years

q: E&P distributions are taxed as ______.
What is partnership special allocation?
o: Allocation of income, gain, or loss different from ownership percentage

q: Special allocations must have substantial ______ effect.
What is partnership Section 754 election?
o: Election to adjust inside basis on transfer of partnership interest

q: Section 754 allows ______ basis adjustment.
What is Section 743(b) adjustment?
o: Adjustment to inside basis when partnership interest is purchased

q: Section 743(b) adjusts the ______ basis of partnership assets.
What is Section 734(b) adjustment?
o: Adjustment to inside basis following certain distributions

q: Section 734(b) applies when property is ______.
What is partnership termination?
o: Partnership ends when business ceases or fewer than 2 partners remain

q: Technical termination was eliminated by ______.
What is disguised sale?
o: Contribution followed by distribution treated as sale

q: Disguised sale rules are in Section ______.
What is mixing bowl transaction?
o: Distribution of property to partner who didn't contribute it within 7 years

q: Mixing bowl rules prevent ______ recognition.
Rearrange partnership formation steps:
What is boot in corporate formation?
o: Non-stock property received that triggers gain recognition

q: Boot in Section 351 causes gain to the extent of ______ received.
What is Section 338 election?
o: Election to treat stock purchase as asset acquisition for tax purposes

q: Section 338(h)(10) is commonly used for S corporation ______.
What is Section 332 liquidation?
o: Tax-free liquidation of subsidiary into parent

q: Section 332 requires ______% ownership by parent.
What is Section 336 gain recognition?
o: Corporation recognizes gain on distribution of appreciated property in liquidation

q: Section 336 treats liquidating distribution as ______.
What is consolidated return?
o: Single return for affiliated group of corporations

q: Consolidated returns require ______% common ownership.
What is intercompany transaction?
o: Transaction between members of consolidated group

q: Intercompany gain is ______ until triggered.
What is domestic production activities deduction?
o: Former deduction repealed and replaced by Section 199A

q: Section 199 was repealed by ______.
What is GILTI?
o: Global Intangible Low-Taxed Income - US tax on foreign subsidiary income

q: GILTI applies to ______ of controlled foreign corporations.
What is FDII?
FDII encourages keeping ______ in the US.
What is BEAT?
o: Base Erosion and Anti-Abuse Tax on certain payments to foreign affiliates

q: BEAT applies to corporations with gross receipts exceeding $______ million.
What is Subpart F income?
o: Passive and certain other income of CFCs taxed currently to US shareholders

q: Subpart F prevents ______ of passive income offshore.
What is foreign tax credit?
o: Credit for foreign taxes paid to avoid double taxation

q: Foreign tax credit is limited to ______ attributable to foreign income.
What is transfer pricing?
o: Pricing of transactions between related parties across borders

q: Transfer pricing must be at ______ length.
What is Section 482?
o: IRS authority to allocate income among related parties

q: Section 482 allocations prevent income ______.
What is FBAR?
o: Report of foreign bank accounts exceeding $10,000

q: FBAR is filed with ______.
What is FATCA?
o: Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act requiring reporting of foreign accounts

q: FATCA requires foreign banks to report ______ account holders.
What is Form 8938?
o: Statement of specified foreign financial assets

q: Form 8938 is filed with ______ tax return.
What is expatriation tax?
o: Tax on covered expatriates giving up US citizenship

q: Covered expatriates are subject to ______ tax on worldwide assets.
What is treaty-based return position?
o: Position claiming treaty benefits that overrides Code provisions

q: Treaty positions must be disclosed on Form ______.
What is controlled foreign corporation (CFC)?
o: Foreign corporation with US shareholders owning more than 50%

q: CFC ownership is tested by vote or ______.
What is US shareholder for CFC purposes?
o: US person owning 10% or more of vote or value

q: US shareholder inclusion is under Section ______.
What is passive foreign investment company (PFIC)?
o: Foreign corporation with 75% passive income or 50% passive assets

q: PFIC rules impose ______ on excess distributions.
What is QEF election?
o: Qualified electing fund election to avoid PFIC interest charge

q: QEF treatment includes current income as ______.
What is mark-to-market election for PFIC?
o: Election to recognize gain annually on marketable PFIC stock

q: Mark-to-market applies only to ______ securities.
What is Section 956?
o: Investment in US property by CFC triggers income inclusion

q: Section 956 treats CFC ______ to US parent as deemed distribution.
What is branch profits tax?
o: Tax on US branch profits of foreign corporations

q: Branch profits tax is ______% (subject to treaty reduction).
What is effectively connected income (ECI)?
o: Foreign person's income connected to US trade or business

q: ECI is taxed at ______ rates.
What is FDAP income?
o: Fixed, Determinable, Annual, Periodical income - passive US source income

q: FDAP is generally subject to ______% withholding.
What is inbound transaction?
o: Foreign person investing or doing business in US

q: Match the transaction type with its description:
What is outbound transaction?
o: US person investing or doing business abroad

q: Outbound transactions involve ______ of income.
What is Section 367?
o: Rules on nonrecognition transactions involving foreign corporations

q: Section 367 may require ______ recognition on outbound transfers.
What is deemed repatriation?
o: One-time transition tax on previously deferred foreign earnings under TCJA

q: Deemed repatriation applied to post-1986 ______.
What is participation exemption?
o: 100% DRD for foreign-source dividends from CFCs under TCJA

q: Participation exemption requires ______% ownership for 1 year.
What is cross-crediting?
o: Using excess foreign tax credits from one category in another

q: Cross-crediting is limited by foreign tax credit ______.
What is sourcing of income?
o: Determination of whether income is US or foreign source

q: Interest income is sourced based on ______ residence.
What is inventory sales sourcing?
o: Based on title passage or production activities

q: Match the income type with its sourcing rule:
What is income tax treaty?
o: Bilateral agreement between countries on taxation of cross-border income

q: Treaties generally ______ withholding rates.
What is permanent establishment?
o: Fixed place of business triggering taxing jurisdiction under treaties

q: Without PE, business profits are generally not ______.
What is limitation on benefits?
LOB prevents ______ shopping.
What is check-the-box election?
o: Election to choose entity classification for tax purposes

q: Check-the-box is made on Form ______.
What is hybrid entity?
o: Entity treated differently in different jurisdictions

q: Hybrids may create ______ inclusion/deduction mismatches.
What is dual consolidated loss?
o: Loss of dual resident corporation that cannot be used in both countries

q: DCL rules prevent ______ use of losses.
What is BEPS?
o: OECD Base Erosion and Profit Shifting initiative

q: BEPS addresses cross-border tax ______.
What is country-by-country reporting?
o: BEPS requirement for MNEs to report key data by jurisdiction

q: CbC reporting is on Form ______.
What is master file in transfer pricing?
o: High-level transfer pricing documentation for MNE group

q: Master file provides ______ overview of MNE operations.
What is local file in transfer pricing?
Local file addresses ______ transactions.
What is advance pricing agreement (APA)?
o: Agreement with IRS on transfer pricing methodology

q: APAs provide ______ on transfer pricing positions.
What is qualified intermediary (QI)?
o: Foreign financial institution with IRS agreement on withholding

q: QIs help with ______ tax withholding.
What is FIRPTA?
o: Foreign Investment in Real Property Tax Act - taxing foreign persons on US real estate gains

q: FIRPTA requires ______% withholding on disposition.
What is USRPI?
o: United States Real Property Interest subject to FIRPTA

q: USRPI includes ______ in US real property holding corporations.
What is USRPHC?
o: US Real Property Holding Corporation with 50%+ USRPI

q: USRPHC determination is based on fair market ______.
What is withholding certificate?
o: IRS approval to reduce FIRPTA withholding

q: Withholding certificates may ______ or eliminate withholding.
What is certified statement under FIRPTA?
o: Seller's statement that they are not a foreign person

q: Certified statements eliminate ______ obligations.
What is grantor trust rules?
o: Rules taxing trust income to grantor under certain conditions

q: Grantor trusts are ______ for income tax purposes.
What is simple trust?
o: Trust required to distribute all income currently

q: Simple trusts receive ______ exemption.
What is complex trust?
o: Trust that may accumulate income or distribute corpus or make charitable gifts

q: Complex trusts receive $______ exemption.
What is distributable net income (DNI)?
o: Maximum amount taxable to beneficiaries and deductible by trust

q: DNI determines the ______ of distributions.
What is trust income distribution deduction?
o: Deduction for income distributed to beneficiaries

q: Distribution deduction is limited to ______.
What is throwback rule?
o: Taxing accumulated trust income when distributed in later years

q: Throwback applies to ______ distributions.
What is estate income taxation?
o: Taxation of income earned during estate administration

q: Estates receive $______ exemption.
What is IRD (income in respect of decedent)?
o: Income earned by decedent but received after death

q: IRD does not receive stepped-up ______.
What is Section 645 election?
o: Election to treat revocable trust as part of estate for tax purposes

q: Section 645 allows combined ______ filing.
What is fiduciary accounting income?
o: Income determined under trust document and state law

q: Fiduciary income differs from ______ income.
Rearrange entity tax forms by complexity:
What is Schedule K-1?
o: Form reporting partner/shareholder/beneficiary share of entity items

q: K-1 is issued by pass-through ______.
What is centralized partnership audit regime?
o: IRS audits partnership at entity level with adjustments collected from partnership

q: The audit regime applies to partnerships with ______ or more partners.
What is partnership representative?
o: Person designated to act on partnership's behalf for IRS audits

q: Partnership representative has ______ authority in audit.
What is push-out election?
o: Election to shift partnership adjustments to reviewed year partners

q: Push-out allows ______ to bear adjustment burden.
What is imputed underpayment?
o: Amount partnership owes for adjustments under centralized audit

q: Imputed underpayment is calculated at the ______ rate.
What is modification of imputed underpayment?
o: Process to reduce imputed underpayment based on partner characteristics

q: Modification considers partners' ______ tax status.
What is administrative adjustment request (AAR)?
o: Partnership's request to IRS to adjust prior year items

q: AAR is the partnership ______ return.
What is BBA partnership?
o: Partnership subject to Bipartisan Budget Act audit rules

q: Most partnerships are subject to ______ audit rules.
What is election out of BBA?
o: Small partnerships electing out of centralized audit regime

q: Election out requires ______ or fewer qualifying partners.
What is qualifying partner for BBA election out?
o: Individuals, C corporations, S corporations, or estates of deceased partners

q: Partnerships and trusts are not ______ partners.
What is penalty for tax-motivated transaction?
o: 20% penalty on underpayment from certain tax-motivated positions

q: Tax-motivated penalties are part of ______ penalties.
What is valuation misstatement?
Substantial valuation misstatement penalty is ______%.
What is gross valuation misstatement?
o: 200% or more overstatement resulting in 40% penalty

q: Gross valuation misstatement penalty is ______%.
What is negligence in tax context?
o: Failure to make reasonable attempt to comply with tax law

q: Negligence penalty is ______%.
What is disregard of rules?
o: Any careless, reckless, or intentional disregard of rules or regulations

q: Disregard penalty is part of ______ penalties.
What is preparer due diligence?
o: Standards for tax return preparers for certain credits

q: Preparer due diligence applies to EITC, CTC, AOTC, and ______.
What is Section 6695(g) penalty?
o: Penalty for failure to meet due diligence requirements

q: Section 6695(g) penalty is $______ per failure.
What is PTIN?
o: Preparer Tax Identification Number required for compensated preparers

q: PTIN must be renewed ______.
What is signing preparer?
o: Preparer primarily responsible for overall accuracy of return

q: Signing preparer must include ______ on return.
What is nonsigning preparer?
o: Preparer who contributes substantially but doesn't sign

q: Nonsigning preparers also need ______.
What is frivolous return?
o: Return based on frivolous position to impede tax administration

q: Frivolous return penalty is $______.
What is injunction against preparer?
o: Court order prohibiting preparer from preparing returns

q: Injunctions are sought for ______ misconduct.
What is Kovel arrangement?
o: Arrangement where accountant works under attorney direction for privilege

q: Kovel provides limited ______ protection.
What is Section 7525 federally authorized tax practitioner privilege?
o: Limited privilege for communications with CPAs, enrolled agents, etc.

q: Section 7525 does not apply to ______ matters.
What is work product doctrine?
o: Protection for materials prepared in anticipation of litigation

q: Work product protects attorney ______ impressions.
What is CPA-client privilege?
o: State-law privilege not recognized in federal court

q: Federal courts generally do not recognize CPA ______.
What is aiding and abetting penalty?
o: Penalty for assisting in preparation of false return

q: Aiding and abetting penalty is $______ per return.
What is promoting abusive tax shelter?
o: Organizing or selling interests in abusive tax shelters

q: Promoter penalty equals ______% of gross income from activity.
What is material advisor?
o: Person providing material aid in reportable transaction

q: Material advisors must file Form ______.
What is tax opinion?
o: Written advice regarding federal tax treatment of transaction

q: Covered opinions have ______ requirements.
What is reliance opinion?
o: Opinion concluding at confidence level that tax treatment is proper

q: More likely than not opinions require greater than ______% confidence.
What is marketed opinion?
o: Opinion used in promoting tax shelter to multiple persons

q: Marketed opinions are subject to ______ scrutiny.
What is OPR disciplinary proceeding?
o: IRS Office of Professional Responsibility action against practitioners

q: OPR can ______ practitioners from IRS practice.
What is censure in OPR?
Censure is a ______ sanction than suspension.
Rearrange penalty amounts from lowest to highest:
What is monetary penalty under Circular 230?
o: Civil penalty for violations of practice standards

q: Circular 230 monetary penalty can be up to $______ per return.
What is willfulness in tax crime?
o: Voluntary, intentional violation of known legal duty

q: Willfulness is required for ______ tax charges.
What is tax evasion?
o: Willful attempt to evade or defeat tax - felony

q: Tax evasion is punishable by up to ______ years in prison.
What is fraud and false statements?
o: Making false material statements to IRS - felony

q: Section 7206 fraud carries up to ______ years imprisonment.
What is failure to file tax return crime?
Willful failure to file carries up to ______ year imprisonment.
What is tax preparer crime?
o: Various crimes for fraudulent return preparation

q: Preparer crimes include aiding false returns under Section ______.
What is conspiracy to defraud?
o: Agreement between two or more persons to defraud the US

q: Conspiracy is punishable by up to ______ years imprisonment.
What is money laundering in tax context?
o: Using illegal funds through transactions to appear legitimate

q: Money laundering carries penalties up to ______ years.
What is structuring?
o: Breaking transactions into smaller amounts to avoid reporting

q: Structuring is illegal even if funds are ______.
What is voluntary disclosure?
o: Taxpayer's proactive disclosure of past tax violations

q: Voluntary disclosure may reduce ______ exposure.
What is Streamlined Filing Compliance?
o: IRS program for taxpayers certifying non-willful foreign account violations

q: Streamlined requires certification of ______.
What is delinquent FBAR submission?
o: Filing late FBARs with reasonable cause

q: Delinquent FBAR may avoid ______ if reasonable cause.
What is reasonable cause for FBAR penalty?
o: Facts and circumstances showing taxpayer exercised ordinary care

q: Reasonable cause considers all facts and ______.
What is willful FBAR penalty?
o: Greater of $100,000 or 50% of account balance per violation

q: Willful FBAR penalty can be ______% of account balance.
What is non-willful FBAR penalty?
Non-willful FBAR penalty is up to $______ per violation.
What is John Doe summons?
o: IRS summons seeking information about unidentified taxpayers

q: John Doe summons requires court ______.
What is designated summons?
o: Summons for corporate returns with extended statute suspension

q: Designated summons suspends the statute of ______.
What is taxpayer advocate service?
o: Independent IRS organization helping taxpayers resolve problems

q: TAS is headed by the National Taxpayer ______.
What is taxpayer bill of rights?
o: Ten fundamental rights of taxpayers in dealing with IRS

q: Taxpayers have the right to be ______.
Match the taxpayer right with its description:
What is CDP hearing?
o: Collection Due Process hearing before IRS Appeals

q: CDP hearing must be requested within ______ days.
What is equivalent hearing?
o: Appeals hearing after CDP deadline passes

q: Equivalent hearing does not suspend ______.
What is CAP program?
o: Compliance Assurance Process for large corporations

q: CAP provides real-time ______ resolution.
What is Fast Track Settlement?
o: Expedited resolution of examination issues through Appeals

q: Fast Track typically resolves issues within ______ days.
What is Post Appeals Mediation?
o: Alternative dispute resolution after failed Appeals settlement

q: PAM uses ______ mediators.
What is arbitration in tax disputes?
o: Binding resolution by neutral third party for factual issues

q: Arbitration is ______ on both parties.
What is Industry Issue Resolution?
o: Program addressing frequently disputed industry-wide issues

q: IIR issues guidance for ______ tax issues.
Rearrange dispute resolution options from informal to formal:
What is closing agreement?
o: Final, binding agreement between IRS and taxpayer on tax matters

q: Closing agreements are on Form ______.
What is Form 870?
o: Waiver of restrictions on assessment - taxpayer agrees to deficiency

q: Form 870 waives ______ on assessment.
What is Form 872?
o: Consent to extend time for assessment of tax

q: Form 872 extends the ______ of limitations.
